evidence.summary: Planning applications for converting a former church in Birstall into flats and constructing 21 homes in Birkenshaw are set to be determined by Kirklees Council's planning committee on July 31, 2025.
evidence.rawText: Two planning applications for new homes – some in Birkenshaw and some in Birstall – are set to be determined next week. The applications to be decided by Kirklees Council’s planning committee on Thursday, July 31 include plans for 21 homes on a plot of land in Birkenshaw which backs onto the local Liberal Club. The site is described as a “heavily-vegetated” vacant plot, previously housing a bowling green and allotments. According to supporting documents, Croft Street was stopped up and closed more than 30 years ago, but is still used for vehicular access to the club and pedestrian access. The former Church of St John in Birstall has been earmarked for 21 apartments. The new two-storey properties would be a range of two, three and four bedrooms and be accessible from Old Lane via Croft Street. The plans also feature a new car park and beer garden for the liberal club. In total, 41 comments have been received in response to the application from members of the public, with 29 of these in objection, seven general comments and five supporting comments. One resident wrote: “The village is already being overdeveloped and becoming crowded; it does not have the infrastructure or facilities to sustain this level of development. The space should be left as a green space and be used to benefit the community as a whole. Another said: “I think this development is a great addition to the area, the contractor is a supporter and contributor to the local area. It will provide better footpaths, car parking and lighting and make the area safer. The developer has listened to the needs of the community and taken this onboard within the scheme. The area has always been an unused and uncared for dumping ground. At least with the new development it will be a nicely maintained area. Kirklees Council officers have recommended that the plans be approved subject to several conditions including that three of the homes are affordable, there is a £57k contribution to off-site public open space and that £10k goes to funding waiting restrictions at the site access onto Old Lane. There are also plans to turn a Grade-II listed former church in Birstall into flats. Plans to bring 21 apartments to Wesley House have been recommended for approval by council officers, unless it is home to bats. The property – formerly the Church of St John – sits off Huddersfield Road and Chapel Lane in the centre of Birstall. The plans have been recommended for approval by council officers subject to the outcome of a bat survey. If bats are found, officers say this would be a “strong” reason for refusal. Wesley House is located within a conservation area. The applicant – Medipharm Bradford Ltd – says that, while the property has been marketed for sale for several years, there has been “little or no interest”. It is now subsequently earmarked for housing. Planning permission was previously granted to convert the building into 21 units but this has since expired.
evidence.title: Kirklees planning applications: Plans to turn former Birstall church into flats and build 21 homes in Birkenshaw up for decision

evidence.summary: A proposed industrial development in Birstall could create up to 150 jobs, with plans for a 7,118 sqm industrial scheme at Norquest Industrial Estate.
evidence.rawText: Up to 150 jobs could be created at a planned industrial development in Birstall. Acting on behalf of Mileway, the pan-European logistics real estate company, P4 Planning has submitted a full planning application for a 7,118 sqm (76,614 sq ft) new industrial scheme in Birstall. The plans will pave the way for the transformation of the land at Norquest Industrial Estate, creating a strategic new hub for industrial, storage and distribution tenants. A spokesman said: "P4 has provided extensive planning advice in relation to the brownfield site, which is designated as an employment area in the Kirklees Local Plan 2019. "This planning application seeks approval for the demolition of an existing warehouse and workshop and the erection of four speculative employment units; comprising two self-contained buildings and a third building divided into two smaller units." Mileway has around 1,400 assets across the UK, Spain, France, Germany, Italy, the Netherlands and the Nordics. Thomas O’Kane, Senior Planner at P4 Planning said: "Our client has been careful to create plans which will transform the site, removing buildings that are no longer fit for purpose and replacing them with modern, purpose-built, sustainable units for a variety of uses. The spokesman added: "When delivered the scheme will deliver much needed investment and jobs which aligns with Kirklees Council’s plans for sustainable economic growth. The scheme, which is strategically located close to junction 27 of the M62, has the potential to create up to 150 new jobs."
evidence.title: Up to 150 jobs could be created at proposed development in Birstall

projects.statusRationale: Insufficient evidence exists to confirm the current status of the Birstall Fallowfield Junction Upgrade project; the latest evidence pertains to unrelated developments in Birstall.

projects.name: East Riding of Yorkshire Broadband Project
projects.description: Expansion of broadband coverage across East Riding to enhance connectivity.

evidence.summary: In April 2024, Quickline was awarded a £44.4 million contract under Project Gigabit to provide gigabit-capable broadband to approximately 32,100 hard-to-reach premises in South Yorkshire and the East Riding of Yorkshire, including up to 600 premises in the East Riding's Goole North, Goole South, and Snaith, Rawcliffe, Airmyn & Marshland wards.
evidence.rawText:
Project Gigabit is the government’s £5 billion programme to enable hard-to-reach communities to access gigabit-capable broadband, which aims to achieve 85% gigabit-capable broadband coverage by 2025 and nationwide coverage by 2030. Gigabit-capable broadband provides a download speed of at least 1 gigabit per second (or 1000 megabits per second). It is at least twenty times faster than the current average broadband speed in the UK will allow you to download a high definition film in less than 1 minute.

As part of Project Gigabit, Building Digital UK (BDUK) carried out a procurement across South Yorkshire and the East Riding, and Quickline has now been awarded a £44.4m contract to provide around 32,100 hard-to-reach premises with improved broadband speeds. Of this 32,100, The East Riding of Yorkshire has up to 600 premises within the contract and the wards that are included within the scope are: Goole North, Goole South, and Snaith, Rawcliffe, Airmyn & Marshland.
evidence.title: Quickline awarded contract to bring improved broadband speeds to hundreds of premises

evidence.summary: In March 2025, Quickline announced an extension of its Project Gigabit rollout, bringing full fibre broadband to an additional 6,000 hard-to-reach homes and businesses across Yorkshire and Lincolnshire, including areas in the East Riding of Yorkshire, backed by an additional £11 million in public funding.
evidence.rawText:
Rural broadband provider Quickline is extending its Project Gigabit rollout, bringing full fibre broadband to an additional 6,000 hard-to-reach homes and businesses across Yorkshire and Lincolnshire.

This expansion is backed by an additional £11 million in public funding, ensuring government investment is directed where it’s needed most.

Project Gigabit is a UK Government funded programme enabling hard-to-reach communities access fast, reliable, gigabit-capable broadband, reaching parts of the UK that might otherwise miss out on upgrades to next-generation speeds.

The newly added premises are spread across all Quickline’s existing Project Gigabit network including in West Yorkshire and the York area (Lot 8), North Yorkshire (Lot 31) and East Riding of Yorkshire and Lincolnshire (Lot 23).

This adjustment ensures that public funding is used effectively, targeting areas with some of the greatest need for improved connectivity based on the latest data.
evidence.title: Quickline’s Project Gigabit Broadband Rollout Extended to Reach More Communities

evidence.summary: In September 2025, Quickline expanded its full fibre rollout in East Riding of Yorkshire, providing gigabit-capable broadband to thousands of premises, including areas like North Cave, Holme-Upon-Spalding-Moor, and Patrington, as part of a £119 million Project Gigabit contract awarded in July 2024.
evidence.rawText:
Thousands of premises in remote parts of the East Riding of Yorkshire are now able to access gigabit-capable broadband for the first time, as Quickline full fibre rollout continues to expand under a £119 million Project Gigabit contract awarded in July last year set up to cover 72,000 premises of which 8,500 have now been ‘passed’ with full fibre infrastructure (although not all of these are part of the government funding).

Among the latest areas to go live are:

North Cave and surrounding villages – over 800 premises in North Cave, Broomfleet, Ellerker, Newport, and Hotham.
Holme-Upon-Spalding-Moor – over 1,100 homes and businesses
Patrington – over 600+ premises
Gilberdyke – over 1,350 premises went live earlier in the summer.
Newport – around 700 premises are now serviceable (remainder of village due soon)
evidence.title: Quickline rollout extends in East Riding, Yorkshire

evidence.summary: In October 2025, Quickline launched full fibre broadband services in the villages of Swinefleet, Reedness, and Whitgift along the River Ouse in East Riding of Yorkshire, providing gigabit-capable connectivity to over 550 addresses as part of the Project Gigabit contract awarded in 2024.
evidence.rawText:
Quickline’s fast and reliable full fibre broadband is now live and delivering high-speed connectivity to rural communities along the banks of the River Ouse.

Homes and businesses in the villages of Swinefleet, Reedness and Whitgift, can now access gigabit-capable broadband with service available to order from Quickline today.

Together, these hamlets represent just over 550 addresses – a small number that perfectly illustrates Quickline’s mission to connect hard-to-reach outlying areas previously overlooked by internet providers.

Located to the east of Goole, the villages form part of the Project Gigabit contract awarded to Quickline in 2024, with more than 75% of the addresses reached, funded through the programme.
evidence.title: Quickline brings full fibre broadband to riverbank communities in East Riding of Yorkshire

projects.statusRationale: Multiple pieces of strong evidence confirm that Quickline is actively expanding gigabit-capable broadband in the East Riding of Yorkshire, with specific locations and contract details in recent years.
projects.locationDescription: East Riding of Yorkshire, specifically areas like Goole and Patrington.

evidence.summary: Planning permission for Eden Project North in Morecambe was granted in January 2022, marking a significant milestone for the project.

evidence.summary: The Eden Project team collaborated with local partners to develop a transport strategy for Eden Project North, including a comprehensive Transport Assessment, Travel Plan, and Environmental Impact Assessment to evaluate traffic and parking impacts.
evidence.rawText: The planning application for Eden Project North in Morecambe was submitted, marking a significant milestone for the £125 million project. The application includes a comprehensive Transport Assessment, Travel Plan, and Environmental Impact Assessment, addressing traffic and parking impacts. Visitor flow will be managed with timed ticketing slots and combined travel and admission tickets. Incentives will be offered for those arriving by walking, cycling, or public transport. Visitors choosing to arrive by car will be required to pre-book spaces in existing car parks in Morecambe or at the park and ride service at junction 34 of the M6 to prevent congestion. Eden will continue to engage with and support the local community and other interested parties regarding future transport plans.
evidence.title: Eden Project North Transport Links Assessment

evidence.summary: The English Regional Transport Association expressed concerns about the Eden Project North's transport plans, emphasizing the need for major upgrades to local public transport and railway infrastructure to prevent increased carbon emissions.
evidence.rawText: The English Regional Transport Association (ERTA) has raised concerns over transport plans for the proposed Eden Project North in Morecambe. While welcoming the scheme as 'excellent news,' they are concerned about the lack of consideration for the level of carbon emissions it might bring, at a time when efforts are being made to cut carbon emissions. The ERTA will be seeking meetings with the local train operator Northern and the Department for Transport to discuss plans for improved rail services, including an hourly service from Leeds. They emphasized the importance of connecting Morecambe back into the country's railway network.
evidence.title: Transport body raises concerns over Eden Project North traffic plans

projects.name: Kirklees Bus Strategy
projects.description: Strategic improvements to local bus services and infrastructure in Kirklees.

evidence.summary: The Kirklees Transport Strategy was adopted following an extensive public consultation from 3 March to 28 April 2025, receiving over 2,112 responses. The strategy aims to deliver a more suitable, safe, and accessible transport network reflecting the diverse communities and landscapes across the district.
evidence.rawText: The draft Kirklees Transport Strategy was brought to Cabinet in February 2025, where approval to consult on the draft strategy was given. Following this, the draft strategy went out to public consultation between 03/03/2025 to 28/04/2025. The consultation received over 2,112 responses from individuals, organisations and businesses across the district, this level of response provides a high confidence level that the feedback is representative. Using an industry standard sample size calculation to achieve a confidence level of 99%, with a 3% margin of error, the survey would have needed to achieve 1,842 responses. Since the survey concluded officers have completed the analysis of responses and the redraft of the strategy document, to reflect the responses to the consultation. The purpose of this report is to present the results of the consultation and engagement activity undertaken, to seek feedback and to seek endorsement so the Strategy can be finalised and adopted. A better approach to transport in Kirklees will help to deliver against core Council priorities: good transport is a core factor in the support of investment and regeneration; it helps places to thrive and allows communities to become more connected. A stronger focus on more sustainable forms of transport, which supports mode shift, will help to deliver a greener, healthier Kirklees and work in tandem with our Net Zero ambitions. The adoption of a distinct Transport Strategy will direct this approach and allow the Council to work to better transport for Kirklees and its communities.
evidence.title: Kirklees Transport Strategy Adoption

evidence.summary: Kirklees Council is consulting on a new Mass Transit network, aiming to create an integrated transport system that supports housing and economic growth, promotes low-carbon travel, and protects green spaces. The consultation runs from 29 January to 12 March 2026.
evidence.rawText: West Yorkshire is planning a new Mass Transit network - a modern, high-quality public transport system that could include trams, light rail or advanced bus rapid transit. These forms of new transport will make the Weaver Network more accessible for everyone. It is a once-in-a-generation investment that could help improve how we travel, support new homes and jobs, tackle climate change and create better places to live. Kirklees Council will deliver the project in partnership with the West Yorkshire Combined Authority, Bradford City Council, Calderdale Council, Leeds City Council and Wakefield Council. This consultation is about how development should be planned around Mass Transit, not the routes themselves. The West Yorkshire councils and the West Yorkshire Combined Authority are working together to create a shared planning framework called a Joint Development Plan Document ('joint DPD'). The aim is to make sure new homes, business spaces, services and public spaces are built in the right places, in the right way, to maximise the benefits from Mass Transit. The Spatial Development Framework (SDF) has been developed by the five West Yorkshire local planning authorities, supported by the West Yorkshire Combined Authority, to bring together our region's ambitions for building, regeneration and a more inclusive economy into a statutory document. The SDF is set out in the joint Development Plan Document. If adopted by the local planning authorities, the Mass Transit Spatial Development Framework will provide a new set of policies for our region sitting alongside local authorities' Local Plans. The Mass Transit scheme is at an early stage with the preparation of the business case currently underway. The UK planning system is designed to support opportunities for residents to have their say on how their local area is shaped by planning. It takes time to develop and approve proposals. Launching a consultation now allows enough time to develop robust and community informed proposals that can be finalised alongside the detailed business case to Government for the proposed first phase of the Mass Transit network. The first stage consultation will run for six weeks from Thursday 29 January to Thursday 12 March. This will inform a further consultation on the Spatial Development Framework in 2026 and allow submission to the planning inspectorate for in 2027.
evidence.title: Mass Transit Consultation in Kirklees

evidence.summary: The Kirklees Transport Strategy outlines the vision and framework for the future transport network in Kirklees, aiming to deliver a more suitable, safe, and accessible transport network reflecting the diverse communities and landscapes across the district.
evidence.rawText: The Kirklees Transport Strategy is a document for the future. It has been shaped by the people who live, work and travel in Kirklees. A transport strategy for Kirklees will help us deliver a more suitable, safe and accessible transport network which reflects the needs of the diverse communities and rural and urban landscapes across the district. Read the full transport strategy: Kirklees Transport Strategy 2025. Why Kirklees needs a transport strategy Transport strategy and policies in Kirklees are influenced by work provided by the West Yorkshire Combined Authority, through the West Yorkshire Local Travel Plan. We will always play a key role at the heart of West Yorkshire, but as there are many aspects of Kirklees which are unique, we require our own specific strategy and policy. What a strategy is A strategy document is a plan for the future. It details the present situation, outlines the goals or objectives, and shows what action you may take to get there. It often includes a vision, objectives and policies. The vision being what you want to achieve, your objectives being the goals which underpin the vision, and the policies guiding decisions that help achieve the vision and goals. A strategy document does not typically include a list of schemes, projects or works to be completed. Instead, it outlines the work that needs to be done to reach a specific goal.
evidence.title: Kirklees Transport Strategy

evidence.summary: Kirklees Council's 'Kirklees on the Move' Environment Strategy focuses on sustainable transport initiatives, including the £14 million revamp of Dewsbury Bus Station to make bus travel more attractive for residents, businesses, and commuters.
evidence.rawText: The transport sector and people's behaviours are changing. From 2021 to 2022, we saw an 8% increase in commuters choosing a more sustainable mode of transport over a private car or van. We're investing in our infrastructure, encouraging behaviour change and making sustainable modes the easy and affordable choice. Dewsbury and Huddersfield will benefit from the multi-billion-pound TransPennine Route Upgrade investment, making the trains more frequent, faster, cleaner and reliable between Manchester, Leeds and York. Walking and cycling within Kirklees has been improved, building on the success of the 7.3 mile Spen Valley Greenway. The Canal towpath between Slaithwaite and Milnsbridge is part of a £2.7 million investment to develop long-term accessibility on a continuous active travel route to Huddersfield Town Centre. A £14 million revamp of Dewsbury Bus Station has been announced to make bus travel more attractive for residents, businesses, and commuters. Coupled with the 'Mayor's Fares' £2 cap on bus tickets, buses are becoming the affordable choice for people to move within Kirklees and to neighbouring places like Halifax, Wakefield, Bradford and Bingley. Local people and organisations are also making a huge difference. Cycle and scooter storage has been installed in local schools through the Mac's Bikes memorial fund to promote active travel by students and teachers, with the charity 'Streetbikes' striving to transform people's lives by providing cycling sessions for all abilities and repairing and re-homing unwanted or donated bikes back into the community.
evidence.title: Kirklees on the Move: Environment Strategy

evidence.summary: Nottinghamshire County Council granted planning permission for six junction improvements on 27 September 2022, including the A614/A6097 junctions.
evidence.rawText: Planning permission was granted for each of the six junction improvements on 27 September 2022. Via is leading this major improvement scheme on behalf of Nottinghamshire County Council and acted as the agent for the planning process. Planning applications were submitted for each of the junction improvements at the end of February 2022. The planning applications were prepared as part of a package to allow the cumulative impacts of the development at each junction to be considered. The planning submission was supported by an overarching planning statement, a strategic Transport Assessment, and an Environmental Statement. Because the improvement scheme at Ollerton is in close proximity to a SSSI (Site of Specific Scientific Interest), a decision was made to undertake a voluntary Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA) and submit an Environmental Statement. This process included consultation with relevant statutory consultees to understand the issues to be addressed in the EIA. A period of public consultation on the planning applications took place to consider all of the relevant issues before the application was decided by the Council’s Planning Committee. The planning application for each junction can be viewed by following the links below: Ollerton Roundabout – the intersection of the A614 / A616 / A6075 roundabout Mickledale Lane junction – the A614 / Mickledale Lane crossroads White Post roundabout – the A614 / Mansfield Road roundabout Warren Hill junction – the A614 / A6097 priority junction Lowdham Roundabout – the A6097 / A612 Nottingham Road / Southwell Road roundabout Kirk Hill junction – the A6097 / Kirk Hill crossroads.
evidence.title: A614/A6097 Planning

evidence.summary: Nottinghamshire County Council provided a statement of case and associated documents for the A614/A6097 junctions improvement scheme, including an Environmental Statement and planning applications.

evidence.title: Statement of case and associated documents

evidence.summary: Worcestershire County Council provided updates on the A38 Bromsgrove Route Enhancement Programme, including progress on flood resilience, safety measures, and site clearance.
evidence.rawText: Work on the A38 Bromsgrove Route Enhancement Programme (BREP) is making good progress. This project is designed to cut congestion, improve travel, and keep Bromsgrove ‘open for business’. Latest updates on progress include: flood resilience has been bolstered by installing large diameter drainage at A38 Buntsford Drive to Charford Road Junction and utilities enhanced through Virgin Media ducting upgrades; safety measures, including temporary fencing, have been implemented, and site clearance is now complete, with sustainable disposal of old street furniture and tree roots. Preparations for the next phase continue with topsoil stripping and ongoing utility investigations; site clearance has also been completed at A38 New Road Junction. Topsoil stripping is underway, and utility investigations are ongoing; meanwhile, at A38/ A448 Oakalls Roundabout, BT/Openreach ducting installation continues at the south side, while Virgin Media ducting has been fully installed on the west side. These are our proposed dates, however as always, we will make every endeavour to complete the work ahead of schedule. If work is completed early, some of the above dates may not be required.
evidence.title: Latest news and progress on the A38 Bromsgrove improvements

projects.name: M62 Junction 29 Improvements
projects.description: Road improvements to M62 Junction 29 to enhance traffic flow and safety.

evidence.summary: The Department for Transport granted development consent for the M60/M62/M66 Simister Island project, which includes constructing new free-flow links and widening carriageways to improve traffic flow and safety.
evidence.rawText: The application will consist of the construction of a new free-flow link (northern loop) from the M60 eastbound to M60 southbound carriageways. Realignment of the M66 southbound carriageway on the approach to the junction. Construction of a new two-lane free-flow road from the M60 northbound to the M60 westbound to replace the existing single-lane, and widen the M66 southbound to four lanes through junction 18. Conversion of the hard shoulder into a permanent traffic lane between M60 junctions 17 and 18, providing five lanes in both directions. Other works will include improvements to signage, signalling and drainage. The application was submitted to the Planning Inspectorate for consideration by National Highways on 2 April 2024 and accepted for examination on 30 April 2024. Following an examination during which the public, statutory consultees and interested parties were given the opportunity to give evidence to the Examining Authority, recommendations were made to the Secretary of State on 9 June 2025. This is the 59th transport application out of 162 applications examined to date and was again completed by the Planning Inspectorate within the statutory timescale laid down in the Planning Act 2008. Local communities continue to be given the opportunity of being involved in the examination of projects that may affect them. Local people, the local authority and other interested parties were able to participate in this six-month examination. The Examining Authority listened and gave full consideration to all local views and the evidence gathered during the examination before making its recommendation to the Secretary of State. The decision, the recommendation made by the Examining Authority to the Secretary of State for Transport and the evidence considered by the Examining Authority in reaching its recommendation are publicly available on the project pages of the National Infrastructure Planning website. Journalists wanting further information should contact the Planning Inspectorate Press Office, on 0303 444 5004 or 0303 444 5005 or email: Press.office@planninginspectorate.gov.uk
evidence.title: M60/M62/M66 Simister Island development consent decision announced

evidence.summary: Costain has been granted development consent for a £138 million overhaul of Simister Island, aiming to reduce congestion and improve traffic flow at the junction connecting the M60, M62, and M66 motorways in Greater Manchester.
evidence.rawText: Tier one contractor Costain is set to begin work on the £138m overhaul of Simister Island, after the government granted development consent for the major upgrade of the junction connecting the M60, M62 and M66 motorways in Greater Manchester. National Highways’ plans include a new free-flow northern loop link between the M60 eastbound and M60 southbound carriageways. The M66 southbound will also be realigned on the approach to the junction and widened to four lanes through junction 18. Other works include a new two-lane free-flow road from the M60 northbound to westbound to replace the existing single-lane configuration, and conversion of the hard shoulder between junctions 17 and 18 of the M60 into a permanent fifth lane in both directions. Improvements to signage, signalling and drainage will also be carried out. Costain was appointed in 2021 by client Highways England (now National Highways) to deliver the design and construction contract. The Simister Island scheme is intended to reduce congestion on the interchange, which carries around 90,000 vehicles each day. Jacobs is acting as delivery partner on the project. Speaking to Construction News last month following the group’s interim results announcement, Costain chief executive Alex Vaughan said the firm expects to begin construction work shortly.
evidence.title: Costain motorway junction upgrade gains development consent

evidence.summary: National Highways has nearly completed the installation of a concrete central barrier on the M62 between junctions 28 and 29, with the scheme expected to finish in August 2023, ahead of the initial autumn deadline.
evidence.rawText: A safety upgrade on the M62 in West Yorkshire is heading into its final phase with lighting and footbridge improvements completing the scheme. National Highways said it has almost completed the main part of the scheme on the M62 between junctions 28 and 29 – installation of a concrete central barrier – and that the scheme is expected to finish in August, ahead of autumn as initially expected. The scheme has seen the waterproofing of the central reserve of two structures, alongside improvements to around three miles of drainage and general maintenance. Scaffolding and encapsulation of the footbridge were due to begin on Monday (17 July), to allow the deck to be lifted from its bearings. Project manager Daniel Edwards said: ‘We appreciate this scheme has already caused delays on the road for many drivers since we began this work in January, and we have done everything we can to minimise delays. ‘We are pleased to say the barrier is now all but finished and we now just need to install the improved lighting. ‘At the same time, we're also going to carry out remedial work to the Dolphin Lane footbridge near Thorpe on the Hill. This will mean we can carry out two sets of work under one section of traffic management without having to put any further temporary barriers, cones or closures in place – minimising disruption to the public.' There will be five overnight closures between 17 and 21 July between junctions 28 and 29 to allow National Highways to put up the scaffolding.
evidence.title: M62 barrier works 'all but finished'

projects.name: Pop-Up Bus Priority Infrastructure Fund
projects.description: A £10 million fund supporting local authorities in Scotland to rapidly deploy temporary bus priority measures, such as bus lanes and gates, to improve bus journey times and reliability.

evidence.summary: The Scottish Government has allocated £10 million to support local authorities in rapidly deploying temporary bus priority measures, such as bus lanes and gates, to improve bus journey times and reliability.
evidence.rawText: The Scottish Government is providing £10 million to support the rapid deployment of bus priority infrastructure by local authorities. Working in partnership with bus operators, the new infrastructure fund will help areas of Scotland with the highest concentration of congestion to implement temporary measures, including bus lanes or gates, which make bus journeys quicker and more reliable for passengers. In turn, this will improve the attractiveness of bus travel by incentivising bus trips ahead of private vehicle journeys. In conjunction with similar active travel measures, it will also help to protect air quality in our city centres.
evidence.title: £10 million for pop-up bus priority infrastructure in Scotland

evidence.summary: The Scottish Government has allocated £20 million through the Bus Infrastructure Fund to improve bus infrastructure across Scotland, aiming to make bus travel more attractive and reduce congestion.
evidence.rawText: The Scottish Government has now allocated £20 million through the new Bus Infrastructure Fund in 2025-26. Meeting the commitment outlined in the Programme for Government, the investment will improve bus infrastructure across Scotland and support the First Minister’s priorities of eradicating child poverty, growing the economy, tackling the climate emergency, and improving public services. The investment is supporting the development and construction of a wide range of infrastructure projects across Scotland – from bus lanes and bus priority signals to accessible features and transport hubs. These improvements are designed to shorten journey times, increase reliability, and improve integration with other modes of transport, ultimately encouraging more people to choose the bus over private vehicles.
evidence.title: £20 million for improved bus infrastructure

evidence.summary: Glasgow is set to trial AI-powered traffic signals on Pollokshaws Road to reduce bus journey times and enhance public transport efficiency, funded by £1.27 million from the Scottish Government’s Bus Infrastructure Fund.
evidence.rawText: Glasgow is to trial the use of artificial intelligence (AI) technology in a bid to reduce bus journey times and enhance public transport efficiency. The project has been funded with £1.27 million from the Scottish Government’s Bus Infrastructure Fund (BIF). The wider BIF was awarded £20 million in 2025-26. It will fund a year-long AI-powered traffic signalling programme on Glasgow’s Pollokshaws Road, which connects the southside to the city centre. Smart signals at more than 20 junctions will use real-time and historical data to prioritise buses and reduce delays. The initiative builds on a smaller-scale trial conducted last year which delivered journey time reductions of up to 50%.
evidence.title: Glasgow to pilot AI-assisted bus priority project in bid to boost efficiency

evidence.summary: Local authorities in south east Scotland have been awarded over £1.2 million from Transport Scotland’s £10 million Bus Priority Rapid Deployment Fund to implement temporary bus priority measures on congested routes.
evidence.rawText: More than £1.2m in funding has been awarded to local authorities in the south east of Scotland for emergency measures to prioritise public transport. Transport Scotland has allocated the funding from its £10m Bus Priority Rapid Deployment Fund, which will support temporary changes to improve bus journey times and reliability on some of the region’s most congested routes. A package of interventions has been developed by the South East Scotland Transport Transition Group, which involves Edinburgh, East Lothian, Midlothian, West Lothian, Fife, Scottish Borders, Falkirk and Clackmannanshire councils. These aim to encourage and incentivise bus travel as an attractive, sustainable mode of transport as lockdown restrictions are lifted and traffic begins to return to previous levels. Amongst proposals are the introduction or extension of bus lanes including on the A90 citybound between Cramond Brig and Barnton and on the A89 eastbound approach to Newbridge, various signalling improvements for smoother flow of traffic and enhanced bus stops at key locations. Led by the City of Edinburgh Council, the South East Scotland Transport Transition Group has worked with bus operators and SEStran to develop the measures, which it is estimated could reduce journey times by up to 12 minutes in some areas.
evidence.title: Councils in south east Scotland welcome £1.2m for pop-up bus priority measures

evidence.summary: The Scottish Government is continuing its programme of investment for over £500 million in bus priority infrastructure to support local authorities in tackling congestion and improving bus services.
evidence.rawText: The Scottish Government is continuing its programme of investment for over £500 million in bus priority infrastructure. The Bus Partnership Fund will support local authorities, in partnership with bus operators, to tackle the negative impact of congestion on bus services so that bus journeys are quicker and more reliable – encouraging more people to travel by bus. The Bus Partnership Fund will complement the new powers in the Transport (Scotland) Act 2019. It will enable local authorities, in partnership with bus operators, to work together to develop and deliver ambitious schemes that incorporate bus priority measures to tackle the negative impacts of congestion. In doing so, this will make bus use more attractive, increasing bus usage and patronage, which in turn leads to greater investment and better services. Work had been paused due to the COVID-19 pandemic, however, the Programme for Government published in September reaffirmed the commitment to this funding programme as a key part of Scotland’s green recovery.
evidence.title: £500 million for bus priority infrastructure

projects.name: Yunex Traffic Bus Priority Measures in Midlothian
projects.description: Deployment of real-time data technology at 15 key junctions in Midlothian to enhance bus priority, improving efficiency and reliability of bus services.

evidence.summary: Yunex Traffic has secured a contract with Midlothian Council to deploy its hosted UTC-UX solution and implement MOVA technology at 15 key junctions to enhance bus priority, improving efficiency and reliability of bus services.
evidence.rawText: Yunex Traffic has been awarded a contract by Midlothian Council to install and commission a new hosted UTC-UX solution and to implement MOVA capability at 15 strategic sites across the region. The new solution will include bus priority functionality at these key junctions, making bus travel more reliable, more efficient and more attractive, to encourage road users to switch from private cars to more sustainable public transport. In conjunction with the MOVA upgrade, a new bus priority functionality will be integrated with the existing Ticketer contactless payment system on the Lothian bus route, which operates south of Edinburgh through the towns of Dalkeith, Bonnyrigg and Penicuik. Real-time data on bus location and timetable adherence will be transmitted to Yunex Traffic’s hosted UTC-UX server, allowing dynamic traffic signal adjustments to be implemented to prioritise buses and optimise bus flow on the route. Vehicle detection at junctions will primarily be by Multi Lane Radar (MLR) technology, with secure 4G communications ensuring seamless data transfer to the UTC-UX platform. Wayne Clark, Midlothian Council said: “Improving the reliability and predictability of our bus services is a key priority for Midlothian Council, as we work to make public transport a more attractive and sustainable choice for our residents. We selected Yunex Traffic as they understood our requirements and offered a cost-effective solution that delivers both enhanced bus priority and a platform for delivering wider traffic management capabilities. Their expertise and innovative approach give us confidence that this project will deliver real benefits for both passengers and the local road network.” Wilke Reints, Managing Director of Yunex Traffic UK, said: “We’re delighted to be working with Midlothian Council on this new project, which will deliver real benefits for public transport users across the region. By combining our hosted UTC-UX platform with MOVA technology and real-time bus data, we’re enabling smarter, more responsive traffic management that prioritises more sustainable travel. This is a great example of how innovation can support modal shift and help build greener, more efficient transport networks.” Virtual trigger locations will be defined and used to request bus priority, with the UTC-UX system configured to action these requests on street and in real time. Unlike traditional SCOOT-based bus priority methods, this project will utilise MOVA for bus prioritisation, delivering a more responsive and efficient approach. The contract also includes the replacement of ST950 controllers and installation of new Yutraffic Actis signal heads at selected sites, providing enhanced visibility, energy efficiency, and durability. These advanced signal heads will improve reliability and reduce maintenance requirements, ensuring safer intersections and supporting the council’s sustainability goals. Yunex Traffic’s Consultancy Services team will play a central role throughout the project, from initial site surveys to MOVA validation to verifying that bus priority requests are successfully implemented. The team brings extensive experience from the delivery of UTC-UX, bus priority and MOVA schemes across the UK, most recently in South Lanarkshire.
evidence.title: Yunex Traffic to enhance bus priority in Midlothian with new UTC-UX and MOVA solution

projects.name: Bus Infrastructure Fund
projects.description: A new fund replacing the Bus Partnership Fund, focusing on delivering bus priority and supporting infrastructure measures to tackle congestion and improve bus services in Scotland.

evidence.summary: The Scottish Government allocated £20 million through the Bus Infrastructure Fund for 2025-26 to enhance bus infrastructure across Scotland, aiming to improve accessibility, tackle congestion, and shorten journey times.
evidence.rawText: The Scottish Government has now allocated £20 million through the new Bus Infrastructure Fund in 2025-26. Meeting the commitment outlined in the Programme for Government, the investment will improve bus infrastructure across Scotland and support the First Minister’s priorities of eradicating child poverty, growing the economy, tackling the climate emergency, and improving public services. The investment is supporting the development and construction of a wide range of infrastructure projects across Scotland – from bus lanes and bus priority signals to accessible features and transport hubs. These improvements are designed to shorten journey times, increase reliability, and improve integration with other modes of transport, ultimately encouraging more people to choose the bus over private vehicles. The investment was announced by the Minister for Agriculture and Connectivity, Jim Fairlie, while visiting the Glasgow Operations Centre at Eastgate – a cutting edge hub that unites key city services to deliver real-time, coordinated traffic, safety and emergency management.
evidence.title: £20 million for improved bus infrastructure

evidence.summary: Transport Scotland announced the allocation of £10 million in Tier 1 funding for 2025-26, distributed to local authorities based on levels of Transport Poverty, with a minimum threshold of £50,000 per authority.
evidence.rawText: Tier 1 funding has been allocated based on levels of Transport Poverty. Transport Poverty is defined as the lack of transport options that are available, reliable, affordable, accessible or safe that allow people to meet their daily needs and achieve a reasonable quality of life. This sees a higher proportion of funding being allocated to more rural areas where access to affordable transport is limited, and areas of deprivation. A minimum threshold of £50,000 has been applied. This methodology was agreed with COSLA.
evidence.title: 2025-26 Bus Infrastructure Fund Tier 1 Allocations to each Local Authority

evidence.summary: The Scottish Government established the Community Bus Fund to support local transport authorities in improving local public transport, with £5 million capital funding and £0.75 million resource funding allocated for 2023-24.
evidence.rawText: The Bute House Agreement and Programme for Government 2022-23 included a commitment to establish a Community Bus Fund to support local transport authorities to improve local public transport in their areas. This fund will support local authorities to explore the full range of options set out in the Transport (Scotland) Act 2019, including municipal bus services. The Transport (Scotland) Act 2019 includes options for local authority run bus services which came in to force in summer 2022. Secondary legislation for franchising and bus partnerships are due to be laid by the end of 2023. The Community Bus Fund (CBF) aims to support this reform by enabling local authorities to complete the preparatory work required, as well as broader innovations and improvements to local public transport with a focus on rural deprived areas where lower population density means bus services can be less commercially viable.
evidence.title: Community Bus Fund

evidence.summary: The North East Bus Alliance, comprising Aberdeen City Council, Aberdeenshire Council, Nestrans, First, and Stagecoach, was awarded £995,000 from the Bus Infrastructure Fund for three projects aimed at improving bus services in the North East of Scotland.
evidence.rawText: On behalf of the North East Bus Alliance, Transport Scotland have today announced the allocation of £20 million through the new Bus Infrastructure Fund 2025/26. The fund is split into two Tiers, with Tier 1 funding being allocated to local authorities based on levels of Transport Poverty (with a minimum threshold of £50,000) and Tier 2 through bids put forward by voluntary Bus Partnerships. Tier 1 funding of £10 million has been distributed through the General Capital Grant with Aberdeen City Council awarded £50,000 and Aberdeenshire Council awarded £510,000. Aberdeen City Council submitted a bid to Tier 2 on behalf of the North East Bus Alliance (which is a voluntary partnership between Aberdeen City Council, Aberdeenshire Council, Nestrans, First and Stagecoach) and has successfully been awarded a total of £995,000 for three projects.
evidence.title: Bus Infrastructure Fund – North East Bus Alliance Award

evidence.summary: Argyll and Bute Council's Environment, Development and Infrastructure Committee approved the use of £414,000 from the Bus Infrastructure Fund to install new bus stops, shelters, and laybys, and to upgrade lighting, aiming to improve accessibility, safety, and service quality in the area.
evidence.rawText: New bus stops, shelter upgrades, lighting improvements – all leading to better accessibility, safety and service quality – will be delivered over the coming months, thanks to funding from Transport Scotland’s Bus Infrastructure Fund. The Environment, Development and Infrastructure Committee agreed yesterday (18 December) that officers should continue to work with Transport Scotland, landowners and operators to deliver this vital programme of work. The £414,000 funding will be used to: Loch Fyne Oysters - Install new bus stops, shelters, and laybys at; West Loch Tarbert – new shelter installation and boarding area in existing Glasgow-bound layby. Rural Bus Stop Lighting Programme – a scalable Argyll-wide programme of solar powered timer or button activated light-up bus stop poles, flags and timetable cases. Guildford Square – roof and seating upgrades to the two existing, bespoke Victorian style shelters in Guildford Square, Rothesay.
evidence.title: Committee welcomes funding for new bus infrastructure

projects.statusRationale: The Scottish Government allocated £20 million to the Bus Infrastructure Fund for 2025-26, with specific funding projects confirmed for various local authorities, indicating active implementation.

projects.name: Fastned EV Charging Stations in Northern Ireland
projects.description: Fastned plans to build ultra-rapid EV charging stations in Banbridge and Antrim, providing up to 300kW of charge to all EVs.

evidence.summary: Fastned has applied for planning permission for two ultra-rapid (300 kW) 12-bay charging stations in Banbridge and Antrim, marking its first venture into Northern Ireland's EV infrastructure.
evidence.rawText: Fastned, which has been at the forefront of European electric vehicle charging infrastructure development since 2012, has applied for planning permission for two ultra-rapid (300 kW) 12-bay charging stations in Banbridge and Antrim. The stations, the company's first in Northern Ireland, will be supplied with 100% renewable energy and allow drivers to add up to 300 miles of range in just 20 minutes. Fastned’s proposed Banbridge station site on the A1 will have 12 ultra-rapid charging points, giving drivers range confidence on journeys between Belfast and Dublin.
evidence.title: Fastned applies for first ultra-rapid EV charging stations in Northern Ireland

evidence.summary: Planning permission granted for a 12-vehicle EV charging station at Bridgewater Park, Banbridge, featuring a solar canopy and associated facilities.
evidence.rawText: Planning permission has been granted for the provision of a 12-vehicle charging station, next to the KFC restaurant at Bridgewater Park, outside Banbridge. The facility will include a canopy with solar glass, associated equipment, landscaping, site access and all other associated site works. The Armagh City, Banbridge & Craigavon (ABC) Borough Council officer report notes: “The site is currently vacant with an existing tarmac entrance to the north east of the site. Immediately adjacent to the site is the Go garage (filling station), Go Coffee and KFC. The approved design for the new EV charging station at Bridgewater Park, off the A1 in Banbridge. Credit: ABC planning portal. The approved design for the new EV charging station at Bridgewater Park, off the A1 in Banbridge. Credit: ABC planning portal. The proposed canopy is to be 30m long and 7m in height, with 12 no. parking bays (9m x 3m) and 6 no. charging units. Each charging unit has the capability of serving two vehicles at once. The charging units are to be 1.9m in height.
evidence.title: Planning yes for 12-vehicle EV charging units at Banbridge shopping centre

evidence.summary: Fastned opens a new ultra-rapid EV charging hub at The Junction Retail and Leisure Park in Antrim, featuring three 400kW chargers and six charging spots, expandable to 12.
evidence.rawText: A NEW super-fast charging hub for electric vehicles has opened at The Junction Retail and Leisure Park in Antrim. The new drive-thru station marks Fastned’s second major investment in Northern Ireland, expanding the region’s ultra-rapid charging capacity and supporting the growing number of EV drivers. The Antrim station features three 400kW ultra-rapid chargers and provides six charging spots, with the capability to expand to 12 in the future. Designed with Fastned’s signature yellow canopy powered by 100% renewable energy, the hub offers drivers up to 100 miles of range in just five minutes. The Antrim hub’s drive-thru design ensures easy access for all types of EVs, making it an ideal stop for drivers travelling to and from Belfast and the surrounding areas. Given its location, drivers can make the most of their time by enjoying nearby restaurants and facilities while charging. Following the successful launch of its Banbridge station in February, Fastned’s expansion in Northern Ireland demonstrates its commitment to accelerating the transition to electric mobility. With ultra-rapid charging currently accounting for just 4.5% of the region’s 687 public chargers, Fastned’s growing presence will significantly enhance the charging network for Northern Ireland’s 23,000 EV drivers. Tom Hurst, UK and Ireland Country Director at Fastned, said: “We’re delighted to open our second ultra-rapid charging station in Northern Ireland. With the Antrim hub, we are continuing to provide drivers with reliable, fast and renewable charging options, helping to build confidence in the EV transition. Northern Ireland has huge potential for EV growth and we’re committed to expanding further to meet the rising demand for clean, convenient transport. Chris Flynn, Centre Director at The Junction, added: “We are delighted to welcome Fastned to The Junction. The ultra-rapid EV station will be a great addition to the scheme, with a huge range of restaurants and cafes, and convenient access to the M2 Motorway, The Junction is a great location for drivers to stop off and re-charge. Fastned has now invested over three million pounds in its Northern Ireland stations and the company is eager to expand further. However, challenges in securing high-capacity grid connections remain a significant barrier to scaling up the UK’s charging infrastructure. To meet the UK Government’s goal of 300,000 chargers by 2030, Fastned urges stakeholders to collaborate and accelerate the grid connection process.
evidence.title: Ultra-rapid electric vehicle charging station is launched at The Junction

evidence.summary: Fastned opens its second ultra-rapid charging station in Northern Ireland at The Junction Retail & Leisure Park in Antrim, featuring three 400kW chargers and six charging spots.
evidence.rawText: Following the launch of its first ultra-rapid charging station in Banbridge last month, Dutch company Fastned has now opened another fast-charging facility in Antrim. Located at The Junction Retail & Leisure Park and described as a “state-of-the-art charging hub”, the new Antrim station features three 400kW ultra-rapid chargers and six charging spots, with the capability to expand to 12 in the future. Fastned say the new hub is “powered by 100 per cent renewable energy” and can offer drivers up to 100 miles of range with just a five minute charge. This new drive-thru station marks Fastned’s second major investment in the north, bringing its total investment here to £3m. “We’re delighted to open our second ultra-rapid charging station in Northern Ireland, said Tom Hurst, UK and Ireland country director at Fastned. With the Antrim hub, we are continuing to provide drivers with reliable, fast and renewable charging options, helping to build confidence in the EV transition. Northern Ireland has huge potential for EV growth and we’re committed to expanding further to meet the rising demand for clean, convenient transport. According to Fastned, ultra-rapid charging currently accounts for just 4.5 per cent of the north’s 687 public charging facilities, serving 23,000 EV drivers.
evidence.title: Northern Ireland gains second ultra-rapid electric vehicle charging hub

projects.statusRationale: Fastned has successfully opened its first ultra-rapid EV charging station in Antrim and gained planning permission for another in Banbridge, confirming the progress of its projects in Northern Ireland.
projects.locationDescription: The Junction Retail and Leisure Park, Antrim

projects.name: Kimmins Launches EV Cross Pavement Charging Trial
projects.description: Infrastructure Minister Liz Kimmins has launched a trial into electric vehicle charging solutions for across pavements for homes without access to off-street parking.

evidence.summary: Infrastructure Minister Liz Kimmins has initiated a six-month pilot to test electric vehicle charging solutions across pavements for homes without off-street parking in Northern Ireland. The trial will evaluate two methods: an engineered channel and a temporary cable cover, aiming to provide residents with access to home charging and cheaper tariffs, supporting the Climate Change Act (NI) 2022.
evidence.title: Kimmins launches electric vehicle cross pavement charging trial

evidence.summary: An estimated 500,000 residents in Northern Ireland without driveways can now apply for cross-pavement home electric vehicle charging channels. The initiative, approved by the Department for Infrastructure, allows residents to charge their vehicles at home, accessing cheaper tariffs and supporting the region's climate commitments. The first installation was completed in Newtownabbey.
evidence.title: Cross-pavement charging now available across Northern Ireland

evidence.summary: London Councils has published new guidance to support boroughs in rolling out cross-pavement electric vehicle charging solutions. The report addresses the challenge of 61% of Londoners lacking off-street parking and the associated trip hazards from charging cables. It outlines options like surface gullies and buried systems to enable safe home charging for residents without driveways.
evidence.title: Electric Vehicle Revolution Hits the Pavement: New Guidance Tackles Trip Hazards in London

evidence.summary: EVA England has launched a national survey to capture the experiences of drivers without access to off-street parking regarding cross-pavement charging solutions. The survey aims to inform policy development and address the charging divide between those with and without driveways, following recent government commitments to support such technologies.
evidence.title: EVA England launches driver’s survey on cross-pavement charging

evidence.summary: Charge Gully has initiated a large-scale trial across four UK local authorities, installing over 60 cross-pavement electric vehicle charging units. The self-closing and lockable cable ducts allow EV charging cables to safely cross pavements, addressing the needs of households without off-street parking and enhancing pedestrian safety.
evidence.title: Charge Gully launches large scale trial

evidence.summary: Transport Scotland has announced a cross-pavement electric vehicle charging pilot backed by £250,000 of Scottish Government funding. Grants of up to £3,500 per household will be available for solutions such as pavement gulley technology or pop-up bollards. The pilot is available in East Lothian, Renfrewshire, and Perth and Kinross, with results to inform national guidance on cross-pavement charging.
evidence.title: Cross-pavement EV charging pilot to inform national guidance

evidence.summary: Charge Gully is starting a large-scale trial across four UK local authorities, installing over 60 cross-pavement electric vehicle charging units. The self-closing and lockable cable ducts allow EV charging cables to safely cross pavements, addressing the needs of households without off-street parking and enhancing pedestrian safety.
evidence.title: Charge Gully Launches Large Scale Uk Trial of Cross-pavement Channel for Safe Ev Charging

evidence.summary: Richmond Council in South West London has launched a permanent cross-pavement electric vehicle charging scheme following a successful trial. The scheme aims to provide more residents with the ability to charge at home, encouraging further EV adoption and allowing drivers to benefit from domestic charging rates, which are significantly more affordable than public charging infrastructure.
evidence.title: London's Richmond Council launches pavement charging scheme after trial success

evidence.summary: The first-ever cross-pavement channel for electric vehicle charging has been approved in Northern Ireland, allowing residents without off-road parking to apply for installation licenses. This initiative enables drivers to charge from their home supply for as little as £3, compared to around £25 at public charge points, and is expected to boost EV adoption across the region.
evidence.title: Cross-pavement EV charging approved across whole of Northern Ireland

projects.statusRationale: The trial for cross-pavement charging has been officially launched in Northern Ireland, allowing alignment with climate commitments, as detailed in evidence from the Department for Infrastructure and Fleet News.

projects.name: Trent Clean Energy Supercluster
projects.description: Initiative to develop a clean energy hub at former coal-fired power stations along the River Trent in Bassetlaw, focusing on sustainable energy solutions.

evidence.summary: The UK government announced a £2.5 billion investment over five years to lead the global race for fusion energy, with the STEP programme at its core. STEP aims to deliver a prototype fusion power plant by 2040 at West Burton, Nottinghamshire, on the site of a former coal-fired power station, creating thousands of jobs and acting as an anchor for a new industrial ecosystem in the region as part of the East Midlands Combined Authority’s Clean Energy Supercluster along the River Trent.
evidence.title: Fusion energy powers UK’s Industrial Strategy

evidence.summary: The UK government relaunched an expanded Net Zero Council, bringing together business, civil society, and local authorities to drive the clean energy transition as part of the Plan for Growth. The Council aims to accelerate the UK's transition to net zero, supporting economic growth and job creation.
evidence.title: Net Zero Council relaunched to supercharge Clean Energy Superpower Mission

evidence.summary: The UK government announced a £28.6 million National Wealth Fund investment in the Peak Cluster project, a major carbon capture initiative. This project aims to decarbonise the cement and lime industry, preventing over 3 million tonnes of CO2 from entering the atmosphere annually and securing thousands of jobs across Derbyshire, Staffordshire, and the North West.
evidence.title: Chancellor’s National Wealth Fund investment in major carbon capture project to boost 3,500 jobs

evidence.summary: The East Midlands Combined County Authority (EMCCA) is advancing plans to unlock new growth opportunities by moving forward with six key projects for potential funding from the 2024/25 Investment Fund. These projects aim to support long-term economic growth, create jobs, and drive sustainability across the region, including the Trent Clean Energy Supercluster in Bassetlaw.
evidence.title: EMCCA progresses with plans to unlock new growth opportunities across the region

evidence.summary: The Invest in Nottingham team toured the former West Burton power station, which is set to become the UK’s first prototype fusion energy plant. The STEP Fusion team is working closely with local organisations to share the project’s fusion journey, raise awareness, and connect with local businesses, paving the way for future success in the region.
evidence.title: Invest in Nottingham explores fusion energy at West Burton

evidence.summary: Bassetlaw District Council welcomed proposals in the Government’s Industrial Strategy that could boost the development of the Clean Energy Super Cluster sites of former power stations along the Trent Valley in Bassetlaw. The announcement includes the STEP Fusion project at West Burton and the Strategic Industrial Sites Accelerator, which aims to attract major investment to redevelop areas like the power station sites.
evidence.title: Government’s Industrial Strategy provides Fusion and Trent Valley Super Cluster boost

projects.statusRationale: There is strong evidence for the development of the Trent Clean Energy Supercluster, particularly the STEP Fusion project at West Burton, supported by multiple government announcements and local council backing.

projects.name: East Midlands Zero Carbon Innovation Centre (EMZCIC)
projects.description: Centre aimed at advancing clean technology innovation to support the region's transition to a low-carbon economy.

evidence.summary: East Midlands Freeport announced plans for a multi-million-pound Zero Carbon Innovation Centre aimed at transforming green research into commercial products. The centre will be delivered by the University of Nottingham and Loughborough University, with matching investments from both institutions. The initiative focuses on decarbonising transport sectors, including aerospace, automotive, rail, and marine, and is backed by £5 million from the East Midlands Freeport, alongside funding from the UK Research Partnership Investment Fund and partner universities. The centre is part of a £70 million co-investment programme and is located at the University of Nottingham’s Jubilee Campus in Nottingham, Nottinghamshire, East Midlands region.
evidence.title: Zero Carbon Innovation Centre gets green light

evidence.summary: The East Midlands Growth Plan outlines the region's strategy for advancing clean technology innovation to support the transition to a low-carbon economy. It highlights the Zero Carbon Innovation Centre (ZCIC) launched in March 2025 at the University of Nottingham’s Jubilee Campus. The ZCIC focuses on decarbonising transport sectors, including aerospace, automotive, rail, and marine, and is backed by £5 million from the East Midlands Freeport, alongside funding from the UK Research Partnership Investment Fund and partner universities. The centre is part of a £70 million co-investment programme and is located at the University of Nottingham’s Jubilee Campus in Nottingham, Nottinghamshire, East Midlands region.
evidence.title: East Midlands Growth Plan Launch Version 1.1

evidence.summary: The East Midlands Investment Zone (EMIZ) focuses on clean energy and advanced manufacturing, providing various incentives to businesses, such as grants, business rates retention, and tax incentives. The EMIZ spans the full geography of Derbyshire and Nottinghamshire, supporting inclusive, innovation-led growth across both counties. Three key strategic sites are identified: Infinity Park in Derby, Hartington Staveley in Chesterfield, and Explore Park near Worksop. The Zero Carbon Innovation Centre is part of this initiative, aiming to drive the UK's net-zero transport transition.
evidence.title: East Midlands Investment Zone

evidence.summary: The East Midlands Freeport is developing a zero-carbon technology and energy hub at the Ratcliffe-on-Soar Power Station site, a 273-hectare redevelopment opportunity. This site is focused on low-carbon energy and advanced manufacturing, offering significant long-term, bespoke investment opportunities. The East Midlands Freeport aims to attract international investment to create tens of thousands of jobs and reinvest hundreds of millions of pounds across the Freeport zone. The Ratcliffe-on-Soar site is located in Nottinghamshire, East Midlands region.
evidence.title: East Midlands Freeport article business.gov.uk international

evidence.summary: The East Midlands Supercluster focuses on the development of fusion energy, with the UK's prototype fusion power plant planned at West Burton in the East Midlands. The Supercluster aims to become a global commercial destination, featuring an R&D Innovation Campus to attract engineering and technology businesses, thousands of net-zero homes, and a £930 million boost to the East Midlands economy. The project is located at West Burton in Nottinghamshire, East Midlands region.
evidence.title: Supercluster - East Midlands Combined County Authority

evidence.summary: East Midlands Freeport announced plans for a multi-million-pound Zero Carbon Innovation Centre aimed at transforming green research into commercial products. The centre will be delivered by the University of Nottingham and Loughborough University, with matching investments from both institutions. The initiative focuses on decarbonising transport sectors, including aerospace, automotive, rail, and marine, and is backed by £5 million from the East Midlands Freeport, alongside funding from the UK Research Partnership Investment Fund and partner universities. The centre is part of a £70 million co-investment programme and is located at the University of Nottingham’s Jubilee Campus in Nottingham, Nottinghamshire, East Midlands region.
evidence.title: Zero carbon innovation centre gets green light

projects.name: Wider Integrated Solutions for Energy, Rail, Road (WISERR) Infrastructure Programme
projects.description: Programme to create investment-ready sites with integrated infrastructure solutions supporting the region's low-carbon transition.

evidence.summary: The UK government published a comprehensive 10-year infrastructure strategy on 19 June 2025, outlining plans for economic, housing, and social infrastructure to drive growth. The strategy emphasizes long-term outcomes, coordination across sectors, and a joined-up approach to improve planning and delivery across all types of infrastructure.
evidence.source: HM Treasury and National Infrastructure and Service Transformation Authority
evidence.title: UK Infrastructure: A 10 Year Strategy

evidence.summary: On 19 June 2025, UK ministers announced plans to invest £725 billion in infrastructure over the next decade. The strategy includes £6 billion annually for hospital repairs, £3 billion for school and college upgrades, £600 million for courts and prisons, £1 billion for road and bridge repairs, and £16 billion for building 500,000 new homes through a new publicly owned National Housing Bank.
evidence.title: Ministers set out plans to spend £725bn on UK infrastructure over 10 years

evidence.summary: A working paper setting out the UK government's plan for its 10-year infrastructure strategy was published on 26 January 2025. This document outlines the government's approach to infrastructure investment and development over the next decade.
evidence.title: 10 Year Infrastructure Strategy Working Paper

evidence.summary: The UK government published the Integrated Rail Plan for the North and Midlands on 18 November 2021. This plan aims to deliver increased capacity, faster journeys, and more frequent services on eight out of the top ten busiest rail corridors across the North and Midlands by developing rail services along with the required infrastructure in these regions of England.
evidence.title: Integrated Rail Plan for the North and Midlands

evidence.summary: The Transpennine Route Upgrade is a major investment in the railway between York and Manchester via Leeds and Huddersfield in the north of England. The project aims to increase capacity by adding extra track, electrifying the entire route, introducing digital signalling, and upgrading stations. The number of fast trains between Manchester and Leeds is to increase from two to up to six per hour, and journey times are to be reduced from 50 minutes to 42 minutes. Freight capacity is also to be increased.
evidence.title: Transpennine Route Upgrade

evidence.summary: The Midland Main Line (MML), a major railway line in the United Kingdom, has undergone various upgrades between 2015 and 2025. The current programme of upgrades began in 2012 and includes electrification of the railway line between Bedford, Wellingborough, Corby, Leicester, Derby, Nottingham, and Sheffield. The routes between Nottingham and Sheffield and the Erewash Valley line were not included at this time, only the line between Derby and Sheffield. The upgrade was part of the High Level Output Specification for Control Period 5 published by the UK Government in 2012.
evidence.title: Midland Main Line Upgrade

projects.statusRationale: Evidence primarily discusses the broader infrastructure strategy without specific details on the WISERR project itself, indicating an incomplete status.
projects.locationDescription: Not specifically identified; broader context is discussed.
projects.locationSource: HM Treasury and National Infrastructure and Service Transformation Authority

evidence.summary: On 28 May 2025, Rail Minister Lord Hendy stated that questions regarding future funding for the Midland Main Line electrification project would be addressed in the upcoming government spending review.

evidence.summary: On 1 July 2025, the Department for Transport confirmed that electrification between Kettering and Wigston is complete, with enhancements south of Bedford due to complete in August 2025, and that a wider portfolio of rail enhancements, including the Midland Main Line, would be published as part of the government's infrastructure pipeline.

evidence.summary: On 9 July 2025, the Department for Transport announced the pause of the next phase of electrification of the Midland Main Line, focusing investment on other schemes over the Spending Review period.

projects.statusRationale: On 14 July 2025, the government announced an indefinite pause of the Midland Main Line electrification, prompting concerns about economic impacts and service improvements, indicating significant delays in project progression.

projects.name: M6 Junction 10 Improvements
projects.description: Upgrade of Junction 10 of the M6 to enhance traffic flow and road safety.

evidence.summary: A £78 million upgrade of junction 10 of the M6 has progressed significantly, with contractor John Sisk & Son appointed to design and build the new junction, aiming to replace and widen bridges to enhance capacity and safety. Construction began in January 2020, with completion expected by summer 2022.
evidence.rawText: A £78 million upgrade of junction 10 of the M6 has progressed significantly, with contractor John Sisk & Son appointed to design and build the new junction, aiming to replace and widen bridges to enhance capacity and safety. Construction began in January 2020, with completion expected by summer 2022.
evidence.title: Huge stride forward in upgrade of M6 junction

evidence.summary: The M6 junction 10 improvement scheme aims to alleviate significant congestion and traffic delays, particularly during peak times, by replacing two existing bridges with new four-lane bridges, widening junction slip roads, and improving local road networks. The project commenced in early 2020 and was completed by 2024.
evidence.rawText: The M6 junction 10 improvement scheme aims to alleviate significant congestion and traffic delays, particularly during peak times, by replacing two existing bridges with new four-lane bridges, widening junction slip roads, and improving local road networks. The project commenced in early 2020 and was completed by 2024.
evidence.title: M6 junction 10 improvement scheme

evidence.summary: As of March 27, 2024, all temporary traffic management measures were lifted from junction 10 of the M6, marking the completion of the final phase of the upgrade work. Drivers can now use all available lanes on the motorway and connecting roads through the junction.
